sources.data_found: SMU NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD: Contains 20 NVIDIA DGX A100 systems; enables high-performance AI workloads.

student_data.notes: Exact current semester enrollment by major is not published on a public HTML page (PDFs are variable). Counts are estimated based on DataUSA/IPEDS 'Degrees Awarded' data for Computer & Information Sciences. Undergrad (BS/BA) estimated as 104 degrees awarded * 4 years = 416. Masters estimated as 479 degrees awarded * 1.5 years = 718 (High count reflects SMU's large online MS Data Science program often grouped with CS). PhD estimated as 10 degrees awarded * 5.5 years = 55. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

gpu_resources.notes:
CLUSTERS & CALCULATIONS:
1) NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD: 20 DGX A100 nodes x 8 GPUs/node = 160 A100 GPUs. (Classified as 80GB based on standard DGX SuperPOD deployments in 2022/2023, though 40GB is possible, specs imply high-performance AI configuration).
2) ManeFrame II: 36 Accelerator nodes equipped with NVIDIA P100 GPUs. 36 nodes x 1 GPU/node (standard config per older docs) = 36 P100 GPUs.

analysis_notes: SMU has a significant resource in its DGX SuperPOD (160 A100s), which is distinct from its older ManeFrame II cluster (P100s). Student counts are heavily influenced by the professional/online Masters programs.
